column2: The Adoptionist Order, founded by archbishop Epilandus of Toledo, tuaght that Christ's human nature existed separately from His divine personhood. The purpose of this order is to promote these ideals and beliefs among its members.
The Conversus of the Adoptionist Order.
column3: Le Conversus de l'Ordre des Bénédictins.
column6: El conversus de la orden de san Benito.

column2: The Apollinarist Order, founded by Apollinaris of Laodicea, a bishop in Syria during the 4th Century. Apollinaris theorized that Jesus could not have had a human mind, but rather he had a human body and a divine mind. The purpose of this order is to promote these ideals and beliefs among its members.
The Megaloschemos of the Apollinarist Order.
column3: Le Conversus de l'Ordre des Bénédictins.
column6: El conversus de la orden de san Benito.

column2: The Iconoclast Order, founded in the early 9th century, follows the belief that any depictions of Jesus Christ would be flawed, either by depicting Him as a purely physical being, or confusing His two natures as both God and Man. The purpose of this order is to promote these ideals and beliefs among its members.
The Megaloschemos of the Iconoclast Order.
column3: Le Conversus de l'Ordre des Bénédictins.
column6: El conversus de la orden de san Benito.

column2: The Melkite Order follows the belief that Melkites are the "original" Christians, and that the rest of Christianity has followed to close to the power of the Pope and Patriach. The purpose of this order is to promote these ideals and beliefs among its members.
The Megaloschemos of the Melkite Order.
column3: Le Conversus de l'Ordre des Bénédictins.
column6: El conversus de la orden de san Benito.

column2: The Monothelite Order, follows the belief that Jesus had two natures (one divine, one human) but one will. The purpose of this order is to promote these ideals and beliefs among its members.
The Megaloschemos of the Monothelite Order.
column3: Le Conversus de l'Ordre des Bénédictins.
column6: El conversus de la orden de san Benito.

column2: The Montanist Order, founded upon the views of Montanus, follows their leader's belief in prophecy and that the church will eventually be established in Phyrgia during the end of the world. The purpose of this order is to promote these ideals and beliefs among its members.
The Megaloschemos of the Montanist Order.
column3: Le Conversus de l'Ordre des Bénédictins.
column6: El conversus de la orden de san Benito.

column2: The Pelagian Order, founded by the monk Pelagius in 380 CE, holds that Adam never incurred any "original sin", only that he set a bad example for humanity. The purpose of this order is to promote these ideals and beliefs among its members.
The Conversus of the Pelagian Order.
column3: Le Conversus de l'Ordre des Bénédictins.
column6: El conversus de la orden de san Benito.
